body.p:
H.S. Henry,
Box 3144, P.O.
CABLE ADDRESS--KENRY, NEW YORK.

Some ten days ago when I happened to
see Judge Isaacs , he asked me if I would reply to a
letter he had received from you (dated 27 July last)
as the subject of the Colony at Vineland. I told him
that I would read the letter, he would not promise to
reply to it. I have to day received a note from him
enclosing yours to him of 16 Inst., and urging me to
reply to you at once on the subjects touched on.

The sudden awakening of our brethren in Philadelphia
after a two years' sleep, to the existence of the Jewish
Colony at Alliance (within 30 miles of this City)
appears to have left them much in the condition
of Rip Van Winkle on his return to the village after
his memorable slumber on the Katskills. They do
not appear to know how and by whom the Colony
was established, or how it has been kept alive and
few did [?] since. They apply to Judge Isaacs for
information which they should know that it is impos-
sible for him to impart, considering that except inci-
dentally as the trusted agent of the Paris "Alliance
Israelite" he has had personally very little to do with
the Colony, which was established by the Hebrew Emigrant
Aid Society of which I am a Resident and which has
been cared for since that Society, practically
ceased to exist by a Committee consisting of myself as
Chairman & Treasurer, Messrs. Gershel, Eppinger & Rosenfeld,
aided by funds raised here under the supervision of
the Revd Drs Gottheill & Heubsch and some remittances
for agricultural purposes from the Paris "Alliance Israelite."

They appear to be ignorant of the fact that about
a year ago, Drs Gottheil & Heubsch visited the
Colony and were so impressed with the necessity of its
usefulness that on their return to New York they made
a collection among their parishioners of over $5000
which was handed to this Committee and used by
them to help the Colonists through the winter--that a
further sum of $3500 was accepted[?] by Judge Isaacs
as the agent of the "Alliance", for Agricultural work
expanded this Spring pro rata among the Colonists.
Finally they do not seem to be aware that when Passover
of this year came along and Matsoth were required
for gratuitous distribution, that an application made
by Dr. Gottheil and others to charitable people in
Philadelphia be a contribution of sufficient Bread
of this description known so well to Israelites and
refered[?] there and that I had to purchase of
Hammerslag & Amram, to the extent of $219 with
out of the funds in hand, necessary for more important
purposes.

I go with these details to show you what has happened
during the Philadelphia slumber-- as you may seem
to be awake and desirous of helping with good work
it will afford me much pleasure to advise as to how
your Society can be best bestowed. We have practically
no funds in hand (barely $200) and having done all
that we think necessary to aid these people in their
battle for life, we have concluded henceforth merely
to protest them in their proprietary rights, and help to
keep alive the Segar industry which furnishes some
wages to those not otherwise employed. I am aware,
however, that some individuals require special
temporary assistance and much good could be done by
a visiting Committee possessed of some means ($1000 is
all would probably be sufficient) to bridge over the
approaching winter. As a rule the 50 families who

H.S. Henry,
Box 3144, P.O.
CABLE ADDRESS--KENRY, NEW YORK.

now comprise the Colony, are good people, anxious
to work and desirous of making homes for themselves.
They have had a hard fight to subdue the land and
to make it yield ultimately something wherefrom to live.
The cost of this establishment has been very heavy
as irrespective of the land we have expended over $25,000
in houses[,] seeding, fertilizing and support during
the past two years. We have weeded out now the inef-
ficient (about 17 families) so that the 50 remaining are
likely to be henceforth less of a burden. The first cost
of the houses you complain of as "mere sheds" &c cost[?] $125
each to which in most cases have since been added
kitchens, cellars & outhouses, then stoves & furniture, so
that the total cost is no less than $200 each. There are
67 houses representing therefore $13,400—no inconsiderable
an outlay to start upon. That these houses are not
altogether weather tight is quite possible--but we do not
propose to go any further expecting that in many cases
the people themselves can help to keep their places in order
and that where they are not able to do so, an occasional
assistance in money would straighten things out—our
observations tending to show us that the more that is
[?], the more is required.

I have the utmost confidence in the [?]
They own one half of the property absolutely—the Hebrew
Em. Aid Society the other half. Settlers were put on
their land and in [?] indiscriminately—contracts
for the sale of the land to the Colonists were given to all
holders identical in character, and it was understood
that no discrimination should be made in any way.
They of course cannot afford to donate the land, but are
willing to wait for payment until the same can be made
by the holders, pending which interest & taxes must be
met. I will enquire with the case of the man
Yassem to which you refer, and will inform you in a

few days how the matter stands. These people sell out[?]
to one another without regard to the debt contracted by
them at Messr Leach's store or the improvements that
have been made as their places and of course they cannot
move in any other direction until the indebtedness
is covered. By right, the first man cannot sell out
until he has paid what he owes in this respect.
The report I have on record of this man "Yasem" is
that his family consists of wife, mother, mother in law
5 children 3[?] 16 years, of age. Shoemaker by trade." He
has done much towards cultivating his land—but
has a sewing machine. He asks @40:pdz[?] for shirts to
Johnson 41 Walker St NYork, where he has a son.

I have not time to enlarge any further on matters
which it doubtless might be interesting for you to
know, but to show you that I am thoroughly desirous
of co-operating with you and the other Gentn. of your
[?], I shall be happy if you will name a day when
it will be convenient for you to meet me and any other
Gent[lema]n [?] who may be desiring [?]to go down
to Vineland. We will sleep in Philadelphia, and take
the 8 o'clock train returning the same evening (West Jersey
road). We can then discuss all matters of interest, and
I can give you personally the information necessary for
you to form a proper judgment of what should be done
further to help these people—in whom I need not
say that I take a deep interest, and with all of
when I am more or less acquainted, having a
written record of all their personal peculiarities.
Hoping to get a favorable response to this request,

I am Dear Sir
Yours [?] H S Henry
